result.title: Starring Katharine Hepburn
result.overview: A look at the career of the celebrated actress, covering the years 1932-1981. Several of her costars and colleagues discuss their experiences working with her; there is a special look at her forthcoming film, On Golden Pond.

result.title: An Audience with Dudley Moore
result.overview: Outstanding comedian and musician Dudley Moore regales his spellbound audience in typical fashion with his hilarious edition of the long-running An Audience With series. Backed by a full orchestra - and interrupted by both Peter Cook and the Dagenham Girl Pipers - Dudley entertains his audience of celebrities (including Stanley Baxter, Martin Shaw, Clive James, Lulu and Rolf Harris) and duets with singer-songwriter Christopher Cross on the award-winning 'Arthur's Theme'.

result.original_title: A zsarnok szíve, avagy Boccaccio Magyarországon
result.title: The Tyrant's Heart, or Boccaccio in Hungary
result.overview: A historical drama set in the 1400s, a young man sent to Italy but is forced back after his father's mysterious death.

result.title: The Colonel Comes to Japan
result.overview: It seems highly unlikely that Colonel Sanders ever thought that he would be selling his Kentucky Fried Chicken to the Japanese, but Kentucky Fried Chicken, Japan, Inc. is doing just that, and doing it successfully. The company, headed by an American director and staffed by the Japanese, has raised the business of fast-food retailing to an art. Here West meets East as the Japanese are shown how to prepare the product and the Americans are introduced to the fine art of Japanese business. –cte.uw.edu

result.title: Iron Maiden: [1981] Milan, Italy
result.overview: Iron Maiden at Rolling Stone, Milan, Italy  1. Another Life 2. Killers 3. Innocent Exile 4. Running Free 5. Transylvania 6. Guitar Solos 7. Drifter

result.title: A Visit to Ogawa Productions
result.overview: A Visit to Ogawa Productions offers a rare insight into the social and cinematic philosophy of one of Japan's best-known documentary film collectives. As the film reveals, Ogawa Productions' in-depth portraits of Japanese society - whether of protest movements or traditional agricultural life - grew out of an unusual commitment to integrate themselves with the communities they filmed, to the extent that their film-making literally became an alternative lifestyle.
